newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Spotlight on the rupiah, Asian regionals pressured.
newsitem.headline: Spotlight on the rupiah, Asian regionals pressured.

text.p: The Indonesian rupiah took centre stage in a still nervous Asian foreign exchange market on Wednesday, plunging to a historic low and forcing a defensive interest rate rise and central bank intervention.
Bank Indonesia was forced to step in after the rupiah shrugged off the rate rise and dropped to the lower limit of its 12 percent trading band.

It fell to a low of 2,682 to the dollar in the afternoon before recovering on the intervention to 2,640/50. The bank's intervention band, the parameters outside of which it will enter the market, was last pegged at 2,378/2,682.
But intervention could well be a losing battle given the continuing weakness in all Southeast Asian currencies.

"It's useless for the central bank to intervene in a bearish market," said Jimmy Koh, regional economist for the I.D.E.A. research consultancy. He noted that the Malaysian central bank had spent some $8.8 billion in intervention measures when the ringgit was under attack earlier this month, but with little to show for its efforts.
The rate rise came as a bit of a surprise as the very rates which were cut last Friday by 50 basis points were raised 100 basis points, so on a net basis policy is tighter now.

"They are raising short-term rates but keeping the long-term rates, which determine lending and spending behaviour in the economy, at current levels," said Manu Bhaskaran, Group Head of Research at SocGen Crosby.
"The central bank has a clear strategy and I think they will use short-term rates where necessary to hold the currency."
Elsewhere, the Singapore dollar remained under pressure but recouped some of its losses on talk of possible central bank intervention near its low of 1.5175 to the U.S. dollar.
It was at a late 1.5100 where dealers said there are strong bids for U.S. dollars.
They said local banks were seen selling the U.S. dollar near its highs earlier, often an indication of the central bank's presence, but no confirmation was available.
A European bank dealer said the U.S. dollar would be bought on any dips to 1.5100 or 1.5050 for an eventual move up to 1.53.

The Malaysian ringgit moved narrowly but showed persistent signs of weakness and dealers said the market was likely to take a crack at the 2.80 level, a low not seen since the ringgit was officially floated in 1973.
"Dollar/ringgit could still reach 2.80 and probably go above that level," said a Malaysian bank dealer. "But I'm expecting some resistance at 2.7850."
The ringgit was quoted at 2.7775 to the dollar against 2.7645/75 at the close of Kuala Lumpur trade on Tuesday.
The Thai baht started easier but regained its composure to trade at a late 31.430 onshore and 31.350 offshore.

Dealers said there were some sales of dollars offshore ahead of the expected mid-August maturity of short baht forward positions, established when the Thai currency came under speculative attack three months ago.
The Philippine peso remained weak as banks bought up the dollar in volatile regional currency markets.
Corporate customers are also looking to buy dollars at the moment and that was keeping the pressure on the peso, dealers said.
The peso was at 28.85 against its previous close at 28.66. Manila traders said the central bank might have sold dollars at the 28.70/28.78 levels earlier but no confirmation was available.

The Taiwan dollar remained weak but fears of central bank intervention and tight liquidity in domestic money markets helped limit any decline. It was at a late 28.726 per U.S. dollar, little changed from Tuesday's close.
